title.value: Characterizing User Behaviors in Open-Source Software User Forums: An Empirical Study
title.justification: The title of the paper directly appears at the beginning of the document and matches the requested title.
title.quote: Characterizing User Behaviors in Open-Source Software User Forums: An Empirical Study

extractions.description: This paper presents an empirical study analyzing user behaviors in open-source software (OSS) user forums. It focuses on the engagement patterns of different user roles such as end-users, developers, and organizers, based on linguistic analysis of forum posts from applications like Zotero, Audacity, VLC, and RStudio.

type.justification: The paper involves a study analyzing real-world data from OSS user forums, characterizing user behaviors through data analysis.
type.quote: To better understand user behaviors in OSS user forums, we carried out an empirical study analyzing about 1.3 million posts from user forums of four popular OSS applications

name.justification: The research primarily deals with human interactions and communications within OSS user forums.
name.quote: • Human-centered computing → Empirical studies in collaborative and social computing

name.justification: The study examines user interactions within online forums, a part of social computing.
name.quote: Empirical studies in collaborative and social computing

name.justification: The focus of the study is on user behavior in open-source software forums.
name.quote: Software and its engineering → Open source model

name.justification: This name describes the dataset comprising forum posts from various OSS applications analyzed in this study.
name.quote: we carried out an empirical study analyzing about 1.3 million posts from user forums of four popular OSS applications

referenced_paper_title.value: How Do the Open Source Communities Address Usability and UX Issues? An Exploratory Study
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper by Cheng and Guo is referenced, which pertains to open source community discussions, likely relating to the dataset context.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Cheng and Guo [5] found that usability specific issue threads are lengthy... in a repository’s issue tracking system such as on GitHub [5, 34, 37].
